a0.speaker: Youmu:
a0.dialogue: These symbols are weird. They look like ghosts circling each other...

a1.speaker: Raiko:
a1.dialogue: These are not ghosts, stranger. These symbols are called 'mitsudomoe'.

a2.speaker: Raiko:
a2.dialogue: Natives of this land except for us can interpret the symbol in myriads of ways. For us, it holds several meanings.

a3.speaker: Raiko:
a3.dialogue: The threefold tomoe in the symbol as well as how they are arranged are taken to symbolize the Trinity.

a4.speaker: Youmu:
a4.dialogue: I haven't heard of this way of interpreting the symbol before.

a5.speaker: Youmu:
a5.dialogue: Most of the time, I hear the symbol represents something like thunder, or even deities like Hachiman.

a6.speaker: Youmu:
a6.dialogue: Or more commonly, the symbol is taken to represent a certain monstrous-looking deity with drums etched with the symbol.

a7.speaker: Youmu:
a7.dialogue: Since all these figures are entities in Shinto, why is there a way of interpreting the symbol associated with pagans?

a8.speaker: Raiko:
a8.dialogue: The Church is always known for syncretizing other cultures' symbols to its iconography.

a9.speaker: Raiko:
a9.dialogue: Notably, Church members in Egypt are notable for taking a very ancient symbol, the ankh, as substitute for the cross.

a10.speaker: Raiko:
a10.dialogue: Of course, such syncretism is important as it can help mask the identities of the congregation from persecution.

a11.speaker: Raiko:
a11.dialogue: Back when House Horikawa was formed, the Shogunate was persecuting Church members very seriously.

a12.speaker: Raiko:
a12.dialogue: As a way to escape it, we adapt the Shinto-looking mitsudomoe as a symbol that represents the Church's important teaching.

a13.speaker: Youmu:
a13.dialogue: All the things you have said are making me think that you are descended from those 'Kakure Kirishitan'.

a14.speaker: Youmu:
a14.dialogue: While Lady Yuyuko hasn't told me that before, I again heard it from Sumireko.

a15.speaker: Youmu:
a15.dialogue: They are well known for taking Buddhist and Shinto stuff as their own in order to escape persecution.

a16.speaker: Youmu:
a16.dialogue: If your concert has it all, I bet whatever your family mansion has will have more trouble.

a17.speaker: Raiko:
a17.dialogue: What did you just say, stranger?

a18.speaker: Raiko:
a18.dialogue: You said the centuries-old crest of House Horikawa is something nonsensical!?

a19.speaker: Raiko:
a19.dialogue: And whatever relating to my family is like a bunch of baloney!?

a20.speaker: Youmu:
a20.dialogue: You can't tell a lie. I feel like your teachings over the Netherworld are ripping off the concepts of the Naraka.

a21.speaker: Youmu:
a21.dialogue: It's based on what I have heard in a poem related to that matter.

a22.speaker: Raiko:
a22.dialogue: Everyone knows that the teachings of the Church are definitely inspired by the Lord before time and space.

a23.speaker: Raiko:
a23.dialogue: Whatever similarities between ours and other beliefs' doctrines are pure coincidence or blatant copycats.

a24.speaker: Raiko:
a24.dialogue: You're turning the Ultimate Truth into Great Lies.

a25.speaker: Raiko:
a25.dialogue: Have I heard you denied the existence and authority of the Lord? Fire and brimstones shall befall!

a26.speaker: Raiko:
a26.dialogue: Whatever punishment awaits you in the Netherworld will be your best nightmare!
